competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing problem: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum(side^2/N) for all N. Key insight: N=1 contributes ~0.66 to score (highest per-tree impact), small N values are critical.

Top kernels use C++ compiled binaries (bbox3, shake_public, tree_packer) for simulated annealing optimization. They start from pre-optimized CSV files and run SA with moves: translation, rotation, squeeze, compaction. Key techniques: boundary tree identification, swap moves, multi-start SA.

Discussion indicates asymmetric solutions outperform symmetric ones. Lattice-based packing with alternating tree orientations (blue/pink phases) is used. Backward propagation from N=200 down to N=2 can improve smaller N configurations.

Academic approaches for 2D irregular polygon packing: 1) No-Fit Polygon (NFP) for O(1) overlap checks, 2) Bottom-left-fill heuristics, 3) Simulated annealing with local search, 4) Genetic algorithms with crossover operators, 5) Hybrid GA + linear programming. NFP is key for efficient overlap detection - reduces O(nm) to O(k) point inclusion test.

Key optimization moves from kernels: 1) Squeeze - scale all trees toward center, 2) Compaction - move trees toward centroid, 3) Local search - small translations and rotations, 4) Boundary tree identification - focus on trees touching bounding box, 5) Swap moves - exchange positions of two trees, 6) Multi-start with different initial angles.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization in 2D?
web_research.finding:
The best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization in 2D encompass a variety of approaches, including heuristic, metaheuristic, and exact methods. According to a comprehensive review of two-dimensional irregular packing problems, heuristic algorithms such as local search, genetic algorithms, and adaptations of classical heuristics like the Djang and Finch heuristic have shown significant effectiveness ([frontiers](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)). For instance, an extended local search algorithm based on nonlinear programming has been proposed specifically for irregular strip packing problems, demonstrating promising results ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305054811001596)). 

Hybrid approaches that combine genetic algorithms with linear or nonlinear programming techniques are also prominent. An example is a hybrid method that integrates genetic algorithms with linear programming to optimize irreg

web_research.query: What is the no-fit polygon (NFP) technique for 2D nesting problems?
web_research.finding:
Teknik no-fit polygon (NFP) adalah metode geometris yang digunakan dalam masalah penataan 2D, khususnya untuk mengidentifikasi area di mana satu polygon dapat ditempatkan relatif terhadap polygon lain tanpa terjadi tumpang tindih. NFP merepresentasikan semua posisi yang memungkinkan dari satu objek terhadap objek lain, sehingga memudahkan proses verifikasi tumpang tindih dan pengaturan posisi dalam proses penataan bahan atau objek secara efisien ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/), [ePrints Southampton](https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/56836), [MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2227-7390/10/16/2941)). 

Proses pembuatan NFP biasanya melibatkan konsep Minkowski sum, di mana polygon satu digabungkan dengan refleksi dari polygon lainnya, menghasilkan sebuah bentuk yang mewakili semua posisi yang memungkinkan tanpa tumpang tindih ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/), [ePrints Southampton](https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/56836)). Pendekatan ini dapat disesuaikan untuk menangani ber
